description: From Middle French vérisimilitude, from Latin vērīsimilitūdō (“likeness to truth”), more correctly written separately as vērī similitūdō; from vērī, genitive singular of vērus (“true, real”), + similitūdō (“likeness, resemblance”).

entries.meaning: The property of seeming true, of resembling reality; resemblance to reality, realism.
A statement which merely appears to be true.
(in composing a fiction): Faithfulness to its own rules; internal cohesion.
